title: 112_s825
content: The "Job Creation Through Innovation Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. Any amendments or repeals in this Act refer to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. After 2011, only the simplified research credit will be used, with an expansion and permanent extension. The "Job Creation Through Innovation Act" establishes the simplified credit for qualified research expenses, where the credit is 20% of qualified research expenses exceeding 50% of the average expenses from the previous 3 years. If no expenses in the past 3 years, a special rule applies for determining the credit. The credit rate for qualified research expenses is 10 percent for the taxable year, with amendments made to sections 41 regarding base amount and basic research payment calculations. The credit rate for qualified research expenses is amended in section 41 to remove references to basic research payments and energy research consortiums. The text chunk discusses amendments to section 41, including the removal of certain subparagraphs and paragraphs related to taxpayer gross receipts and research expenses. Additionally, subsections (d) and (h) are amended for a permanent extension, and cross-references in section 45C(b)(1) are also modified. Amendments are made to various sections including 41, 45C, and 45G by striking certain references and inserting new ones. Subsection (g) of section 45O is also amended. Amendments are made to various sections including 41, 45C, and 45G by striking certain references and inserting new ones. Subsection (g) of section 45O is also amended, with changes to subparagraphs in sections 54(l)(3), 170(e)(4)(B), and 170(e)(4). The term 'qualified organization' is defined for educational purposes. The text chunk discusses amendments to section 197 related to educational organizations described in section 501(c)(3) and exempt from tax under section 501(a) primarily conducting scientific research. Amendments are made to section 280C, including changes to subsections (b)(3) and (c)(1) and (2), replacing references to section 41(f) with section 41(d). Subclause (IV)(c) of section 936(h)(5)(C)(i) is also affected. Amendments are made to various sections, including section 936, 965, and 1400N, by replacing references to section 41(f) with section 41(d). Additionally, technical corrections are made to section 409. Amendments are made to various sections by inserting specific references before the enactment of the Tax Reform Act of 1984. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, with technical corrections taking effect upon the enactment of the Act. Enhanced research credit for domestic manufacturers starting after December 31, 2011. The text introduces an enhanced credit for domestic manufacturers, where a qualified domestic manufacturer can increase the 20 percent credit by a bonus amount. A qualified domestic manufacturer is defined as a taxpayer with domestic production gross receipts exceeding 50 percent of total production gross receipts. The term 'total production gross receipts' refers to the taxpayer's gross receipts described in section 199(c)(4), determined without considering the origin of the property and by substituting 'any property described in section 168(f)(3)' for 'any qualified film'. The bonus amount for paragraph (1) is determined without regard to where construction or services were performed in the United States. The bonus amount for different percentage ranges of total production gross receipts is determined by increasing percentage points. The effective date for the amendment is after December 31, 2011. Additionally, the research credit is made refundable for small businesses. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a portion of the research credit to be refundable for qualified small businesses. The term 'qualified small business' refers to a person with 500 or fewer employees in a taxable year. Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended. These changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011. SEC. 5. Extension of grants for specified energy property in lieu of tax credits, amending subsection (a) of section 1603 of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 to extend deadlines to 2012 and 2013. SEC. 6. Extension of the advanced energy project credit. The Secretary will establish a program to award certifications for qualified investments eligible for credits under section 48C to advanced energy project sponsors. The total amount of credits allocated shall not exceed the 2011 allocation. The program described in subparagraph (A) shall not exceed the 2011 allocation amount reduced by any increase in the limitation under paragraph (1)(B). Rules similar to paragraphs (2), (3), (4), and (5) apply, with applicants having 2 years to submit applications and specific criteria for domestic job creation. The creation of direct and indirect jobs in the United States for property manufactured at a specific facility, with a separate review and redistribution to be conducted by the Secretary within 4 years. The term '2011 allocation amount' is defined for this subsection. The term '2011 allocation amount' is defined as $5,000,000,000. In lieu of a qualifying advanced energy project credit, the Secretary can grant the taxpayer the amount of the credit. A portion of the 2011 allocation is allocated towards pending applications under the original program, with a limit of $1,500,000,000. The Secretary can allocate up to $1,500,000,000 for qualified investments from the 2011 allocation amount. A conforming amendment is made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code.
